awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Ultrafast Time/Frequency Domain Coherent Anti-Stokes Raman Spectroscopy for Combustion and Plasma Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: 

Optimization of combustion and plasma systems is important for a wide range of applications, from clean power generation to materials processing.  The objective of this research is to significantly enhance the knowledge and understanding of non-equilibrium gas-phase chemistry in novel combustion and plasma systems through the development and use of a new laser spectroscopic approach known as ultrafast time/frequency domain coherent anti-Stokes Raman spectroscopy.  This technique has the potential to overcome many of the shortcomings of conventional laser diagnostic approaches by enabling simultaneous characterization of temperature- and pressure-dependent energy transfer processes on a time scale that can resolve molecular collisions, vibrational and rotational energy levels within single and multiple species, as well as resonant and non-resonant time dynamics.  Preliminary data indicate that these processes can be studied at measurement rates that are at least one hundred times faster than previous spectroscopic approaches, allowing transients in many practical devices to be resolved with unprecedented detail.  The development and validation of a time-dependent theoretical model to capture the fundamental photophysics of ultrafast laser-matter interactions will take place in parallel with, and in many cases, guide the development of experimental innovations.  

Broader Impact: 

The broad impact of this research will be achieved, in part, by advancing the detailed understanding of gas-phase chemistry that is important for meeting current and future challenges in clean energy and manufacturing.  Applications that benefit society include the development of chemical and molecular dynamics simulations of surface (or gas-solid) chemistry, high-pressure coal/biomass gasification, emissions reduction in combustion devices, catalytic upgrading and utilization of alternative fuels, electric discharges for boundary flow control, plasma-assisted ignition/combustion, plasma synthesis of nanotubes, and plasma deposition of silicon alloys for solar energy conversion. Strategies such as homogeneous charge compression ignition and oxy-fuel combustion, for example, invoke unconventional operating conditions, and experimental methods are required to help develop and validate models of chemical kinetics and energy transfer processes for a range of temperatures and pressures.  The scientific knowledge gained through this work will be disseminated broadly through scholarly publications and collaboration with academia, industry, and national laboratories. The integrated research and education plan includes expansion of joint research and education activities through the Program for Women in Science and Engineering, as well as NSF sponsored Research Experiences for Undergraduates and Research Experiences for Teachers.  Graduate students will gain experience in teaching and mentoring undergraduate students both in the laboratory and classroom, as well as inspiring k-12 students through a new program they have already piloted called "Engineering at the Speed of Light."  The knowledge gained through this work will also be used for an advanced combustion course attended by graduate and undergraduate students, as well as expansion of curricula through the establishment of an Energy Systems minor in the College of Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The goal this work was to enhance the knowledge and understanding of high-pressure and non-equilibrium gas-phase chemistry and energy transfer in combustion and plasma systems through the development and use of a new laser diagnostic approach, referred to as hybrid femtosecond/picosecond coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (fs/ps CARS). This technique utilizes the advantages of time and frequency domain spectroscopy to overcome many of the shortcomings of conventional diagnostic approaches and has the potential to produce a transformative impact on the design and optimization of novel energy conversion systems operating far from equilibrium. This includes advanced power generation, propulsion, and materials processing systems.

 

A key project outcome includes the development and validation of a theoretical, time-dependent model of ultrafast time/frequency domain CARS at high pressures and nonequilibrium conditions. This model is compared with experimental measurements to determine the rotational and vibrational states of the gas phase species, incorporate the effects of molecular collisions on the temporal evolution of those states, and establish key spectroscopic parameters for linewidths and line mixing in the theoretical spectra. This model has been published in literature and shared with other laboratories who now utilize this technique.

 

Key experimental outcomes of this work include the development of novel measurement modalities and the optimization of the accuracy and precision of the technique. This project demonstrated the first use of fs/ps CARS for (1) measurements over a wide temperature range in flames from 300 K to 2300 K, (2) measurements at kHz rates, (3) the simultaneous measurement of temperature and multiple species in multi-component mixtures, (4) the simultaneous measurement of rotational and vibrational spectra for capturing thermal non-equilibrium in plasmas, (5) the measurement of biomass pyrolysis products, and (6) the measurement of combustion at high temperatures and pressures. Various pulse-shaping methods were utilized to generate ps pulses for optimizing the accuracy and precision of the technique under different operating conditions.

 

This work has been disseminated in 10 archival journal publications thus far, numerous conference papers and presentations, and invited talks at national and international conferences. It has also inspired the use of fs/ps CARS in multiple universities and national laboratories. Universities who have utilized this measurement approach now include Iowa State University, Purdue University, the University of Virginia, Lund University in Sweden, Erlangen University in Germany, and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. National laboratories include Sandia National Laboratories in Livermore and Albuquerque, the Air Force Research Laboratory, the Naval Research Laboratory, and NASA. Follow-on work by other researchers has enabled the extension of CARS to gas-phase planar measurements at kHz rates for the first time. It has also led to measurements of transient heat transfer near surfaces, measurements in sooting flames, studies of energetic materials, investigation of plasma-assisted combustion, and measurement of pressure for high-speed flows. It is also being considered for use in studying catalysis, internal combustion engines, space propulsion, high-pressure flame chemistry, supersonic flows, and rotating detonation engines.

 

Key educational outcomes of this project include the training of a diverse workforce and mentoring of doctoral students who have taken positions in national laboratories and academia. A student who started as freshman honors student working on this project and continued on through her PhD recently joined a major research university as a tenure track assistant professor. A former post-doctoral researcher mentored by the PI has also been able to acquire a position as assistant professor after working in the PI’s laboratory, and the use of fs/ps CARS has played a significant role in his early research efforts in collaboration with the PI. The first PhD student working on the project joined the Air Force Research Laboratory after his tenure as a National Research Council Post-doctoral Research Associate. A number of other graduate students have been trained in fs/ps CARS and will be using this in subsequent work in space propulsion and high-pressure combustion studies. A number of high-school and undergraduate students, including a number of women and underrepresented minorities, have also been able to gain significant experience in the PI’s laboratory and inspired towards graduate school. By developing interdisciplinary research and educational programs involving k-12, undergraduate, and graduate students, the PI has helped to inspire and train engineers who are equipped with the knowledge and tools to solve current and future challenges in sustainable energy.
